summary: In Thompson v. Mensah, the plaintiff claimed ownership and possession of land in Accra based on deeds from 1944–1945 derived solely from the Korle We. The land was held under the Ga and Gbese Stools and Korle We, with prior authority requiring consent from all three for an absolute alienation. The plaintiff, having never been in possession, failed to plead reliance on grants from multiple stools. During trial, he introduced deeds dated October 31, 1956, from the Gbese Mantse, purporting to confirm prior grants, but these were inadmissible due to lack of proof of execution and absence of required statutory consents. The Court held that the plaintiff could not rely on unstipulated grantors without amending pleadings, that the deeds could not retrospectively confirm extinguished interests, and that failure to obtain Ga Stool consent invalidated the claim for an absolute estate. Even as to a determinable estate, the claim failed due to lack of assent from the family in possession. The family’s grant to the defendant did not constitute forfeiture, and the stools’ acquiescence barred enforcement. The defendant, being in possession, was entitled to protection. The appeal was dismissed.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; plaintiff's claim failed on multiple grounds including defective pleading, lack of required consents, and inadmissible evidence.
citations: Golightly and Another v. Ashrifi and Others (1955) 14 W.A.C.A. 676
Adumua-Bossman v. Bannerman, West African Court of Appeal, February 27, 1957, unreported
Baidoo v. Osei and Owusu (1958) 3 W.A.L.R. 289
rationaleHighlights: Failure to amend pleadings barred reliance on new grantors
Deeds executed post-hearing and without required consents were void
Grantees lacked interest at time of purported confirmation, making deeds ineffective
Alienation of absolute estate required consent of all controlling stools
Act by family in possession did not amount to denial of title warranting forfeiture
Acquiescence by stool barred forfeiture claim
Consent of controlling stool not required for alienation of determinable estate to another stool-subject
Possession entitled defendant to protection even with defective title
